questions.text: A 6-year-old child sustained lateral condyle humerus fracture. The fracture united but gradually he developed a deformity. Which of the following clinical sign you expect to find in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loss of adduction-abduction of fingers

 

Option D)

 

  • The loss of adduction and abduction of the fingers is primarily associated with ulnar nerve dysfunction, which can be a consequence of humeral fractures.
  • The lateral condyle area is particularly relevant, as improper healing or malunion can lead to tension or damage to the ulnar nerve as it runs near the elbow.
  • If the fracture site leads to ulnar nerve entrapment or a deformity that alters the position of the elbow, it could impair the function of muscles responsible for the fine motor control of finger abduction and adduction (like the interossei).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Ape thumb deformity: Ape thumb deformity occurs when the thumb is positioned in line with the other fingers, making it unable to oppose. This is typically associated with injury of the median nerve, leading to weakness in the thenar muscles. In the context of a lateral condyle fracture, this is less likely unless there was direct injury to the median nerve, which is uncommon.

 

 

Option B) Pointing index sign: The pointing index sign occurs when the patient can extend the index finger while the other fingers are flexed, often due to median nerve damage. In children with fractures of the humerus, this might be seen if the injury affected the median nerve. However, this sign specifically indicates issues with the median nerve, not directly related to the complications of a lateral condyle fracture.

 

Option C) Wrist drop: Wrist drop is a clinical sign indicative of radial nerve injury, characterized by the inability to extend the wrist and fingers, leading to a "dropped" appearance. While the radial nerve can be affected by humeral fractures, especially those involving the lateral condyle, wrist drop would not typically present as a direct result of a healed fracture that has caused deformity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Loss of adduction and abduction of fingers, directly ties to potential ulnar nerve involvement due to the fracture's anatomical implications and healing process.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents with worsening shoulder pain. X-rays reveal a lytic lesion in the humeral head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metastatic disease

 

Option C)

 

  • Metastatic disease occurs when cancer cells spread from their primary site to other parts of the body, including the bones.
  • Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers that metastasizes to the bones, along with prostate and lung cancers.
  • Patients with metastatic bone disease often experience localized pain, which may worsen over time.
  • Lytic lesions (areas of bone destruction) are commonly seen on imaging studies.
  • The humeral head is a potential site for metastasis in breast cancer patients.
  • The diagnosis is typically confirmed through imaging studies (X-rays, CT, or MRI) and may require a biopsy to determine the histology.
  • The lytic lesion in this context strongly suggests metastatic disease, especially given the patient’s history of breast cancer.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and the underlying bone, leading to joint pain and stiffness. OA typically results from a combination of factors, including age, wear and tear on the joints, obesity, and previous joint injuries. Patients with OA may present with joint pain, swelling, and reduced range of motion. Pain is usually worse with activity and improves with rest. X-rays typically show joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis, but not lytic lesions. Diagnosis is based on clinical history, physical examination, and imaging studies. In this case, the presence of a lytic lesion is not consistent with osteoarthritis.

 

Option B) Primary Bone Tumour: Primary bone tumours are tumours that originate in the bone itself. They can be benign or malignant. Common primary malignant bone tumours include osteosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma, and chondrosarcoma. Patients may experience localized pain, swelling, and sometimes systemic symptoms like fever or weight loss. Imaging studies may show lytic or sclerotic lesions, depending on the tumour type. However, primary bone tumours are more common in younger individuals and are less likely to occur in someone with a history of cancer. Diagnosis often involves imaging and biopsy. While possible, the context of a known history of breast cancer makes this less likely than metastatic disease.

 

Option D) Avascular Necrosis: Avascular necrosis, also known as osteonecrosis, is the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply. AVN can be caused by trauma, prolonged use of corticosteroids, alcoholism, or certain medical conditions. Patients may present with joint pain, especially during weight-bearing activities. Imaging may show areas of bone collapse or cystic changes, but AVN typically presents with more subchondral changes rather than lytic lesions. Diagnosis is based on clinical history, imaging studies (X-rays or MRI), and the presence of risk factors. The description of a lytic lesion in the context of this patient's history does not align with AVN.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Metastatic Disease aligns with the common presentation of breast cancer metastasizing to the bones, particularly in the context of a known malignancy.
  • Lytic lesions (areas of bone destruction) are commonly seen on imaging studies.

questions.text: Caries sicca is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder

 

Option B:

 

  • Tuberculosis of shoulder is dry with no effusion.
  • This is known as caries sicca.
  • Caries sicca is a fairly rare extrapulmonary presentation of bone tuberculosis.
  • It accounts for 0.9-1.7% of all extrapulmonary tuberculosis cases.
  • Males are more commonly affected than females.
  • Head of humerus is affected, and progresses to involve glenoid cavity and joint space.
  • It presents with degenerative changes in shoulder joint, associated with pain that aggravated on movements.
  • Reduction in joint space is a delayed finding.
  • Advanced cases leads to inferior subluxation of the humeral head, and fibrous ankyloses.
  • The patient presents with insidious onset pain, often at night.
  • On examination, there is shoulder muscle atrophy, prominent bony landmarks, reduced and painful movements in all directions, and generalized tenderness.
  • It is often misdiagnosed as adhesive capsulitis.
  • Radiologically, phemister’s triad is seen which includes periarticular osteoporosis, peripheral local bony erosion, and gradual narrowing of joint space.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Caries sicca is the tuberculosis of the shoulder which is dry, without any exudate.

questions.text: Purulent inflammation and infection of terminal pulp space of distal phalanges is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Whitlow or felon 

 

  • A felon is a specific type of infection that occurs in the pulp space of the fingertip (distal phalanx). 
  • It is commonly caused by trauma, leading to bacterial infection (often Staphylococcus aureus).
  • Patients experience severe pain, swelling, and a tense, fluctuant area at the fingertip, often with a visible abscess. 
  • Whitlow can refer to a herpetic infection of the fingers, but in the context of purulent inflammation, it specifically indicates a felon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Paronychium: Paronychium refers to the tissue surrounding the nail. Acute paronychium is an infection of the nail fold, often caused by bacteria or fungi, resulting in inflammation and pus formation. Patients typically present with swelling, redness, and pain around the nail, which may also exhibit purulent discharge. It is often related to trauma or irritants.

 

Option C. Acute Suppurative Tenosynovitis: This condition involves inflammation of the synovial sheath surrounding a tendon, often due to infection. It can occur in various locations, including the hands. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and restricted motion of the affected tendon. The infection can lead to purulent fluid accumulation, but the focus is on the tendon sheath rather than the pulp space of the distal phalanx. While it can be purulent, it does not specifically refer to the pulp space infection of the distal phalanx.

 

Option D. Apical Subungual Infection: This refers to an infection occurring beneath the nail (subungual area), often resulting from trauma or a foreign body. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and discharge near the nail area, potentially leading to nail dystrophy. While it can be purulent, it typically does not involve the pulp space itself. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whitlow or felonspecifically refers to a purulent infection in the pulp space of the distal phalanges, making it the correct answer.

questions.text: All are diagnostic features of osteomalacia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased Serum Calcium

 

Option A)

 

  • In osteomalacia, serum calcium levels are typically normal or may even be low due to poor absorption of calcium from the intestines, especially in cases of vitamin D deficiency.

  • The body attempts to compensate for low calcium levels by mobilizing calcium from bones and increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, which may affect bone health but usually does not result in elevated serum calcium.

  • This is not a diagnostic feature of osteomalacia.

  • An increased serum calcium level would more likely suggest conditions like hyperparathyroidism or other disorders, not osteomalacia.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Increased Alkaline Phosphatase: Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is an enzyme related to bone turnover and is often elevated in conditions that involve bone formation or remodeling. In osteomalacia, alkaline phosphatase levels are typically increased due to the increased osteoblastic activity in response to inadequate mineralization of bone. This elevation serves as a compensatory mechanism as the body attempts to mineralize the osteoid matrix. This is a diagnostic feature of osteomalacia. Increased alkaline phosphatase levels indicate that the bones are actively trying to remodel and mineralize.

 

Option C) Proximal Myopathy: Proximal myopathy refers to muscle weakness that primarily affects the proximal muscles. Patients with osteomalacia may experience muscle weakness and discomfort, particularly in the proximal muscle groups. This is thought to be due to the effects of vitamin D deficiency on muscle health, along with the overall skeletal pain and weakness resulting from the disorder. This is a diagnostic feature of osteomalacia. Proximal myopathy is often noted in patients with vitamin D deficiency and osteomalacia.

 

Option D) Looser’s Zone: Looser's zones, or pseudofractures, are areas of unmineralized osteoid found in bones affected by osteomalacia. These radiological findings appear as well-defined areas of bone density loss, often resembling fractures but occurring without the usual trauma. They are indicative of insufficient mineralization and are a hallmark of osteomalacia. This is a diagnostic feature of osteomalacia. The presence of Looser's zones on X-rays is a significant finding that supports a diagnosis of osteomalacia.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Increased serum calcium level is the exception among the choices, as osteomalacia does not typically present with increased serum calcium levels.

  • The other options are all consistent with the diagnosis of osteomalacia.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: Which HLA is associated with Reiter’s syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HLA B27

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is inflammatory arthritis that manifests after several days to weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection.
  • It is also described as a classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. However, a majority of patients do not present with the classic triad.
  • It is known to be triggered by a bacterial infection, particularly of the genitourinary (Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, Mycoplasma hominis, and Ureaplasma urealyticum) or gastrointestinal (GI) tract (Salmonella enteritidis, Shigella flexneri, and S. disenteriae, Yersinia enterocolitica, Campylobacter jejuni, Clostridium difficile).
  • The incidence is about 2-4% after a urogenital infection, mainly with Chlamydia trachomatis, and varies from 0-15% after gastrointestinal infections with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Yersinia.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated syndrome triggered by a recent infection.
    • It is hypothesized that T lymphocytes are induced by bacterial fragments such as lipopolysaccharide and nucleic acids when invasive bacteria reach the systemic circulation.
    • These activated cytotoxic-T cells attack the synovium and other self-antigens through molecular mimicry.
    • It is believed that anti-bacterial cytokine response is also impaired in reactive arthritis, resulting in decreased bacteria elimination.
    • The prevalence of HLA-B27 in reactive arthritis is estimated at 30-50% in patients with reactive arthritis.
    • HLA-B27 should not be used as a diagnostic tool for diagnosing acute ReA.
    • The presence of HLA-B27 is believed to potentiate reactive arthritis by presenting bacterial antigens to T cells, altering the self-tolerance of the host immune system, increasing tumor necrosis factor-alpha production, promoting the invasion of microbes in the gut, and delaying clearance of causative organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. HLA DR3: This allele is more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus, rather than with reactive arthritis.

 

Option. C. HLA DR4: This allele is most notably associated with rheumatoid arthritis, especially in individuals who have severe disease forms.

 

Option. D. HLA DQ8: This HLA subtype is also more commonly associated with type 1 diabetes and not typically linked with reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis.
  • Approximately 75-80% of patients with reactive arthritis test positive for HLA-B27.
  • But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of bone scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioisotope bone scan

 

Option A)

 

  • A radioisotope bone scan, also known as a bone scintigraphy, is a diagnostic imaging technique that uses small amounts of radioactive material (radioisotopes) to visualize bone metabolism and detect abnormalities.

  • A radioisotope (commonly technetium-99m) is injected into a vein, and after a few hours, a special camera captures images of the bones.

  • Areas with increased or decreased activity may indicate conditions such as fractures, infections, tumours, or arthritis.

  • This scan is useful for diagnosing bone-related conditions, assessing the extent of disease, and guiding treatment decisions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Bone Densitometry: Bone densitometry, commonly referred to as a DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) scan, is a technique used to measure bone mineral density (BMD). It involves using low-dose X-rays to assess the density of bones, typically at the hip and spine, to evaluate the risk of osteoporosis and fractures. This scan is primarily used for diagnosing osteoporosis, monitoring bone density changes over time, and assessing fracture risk.

 

Option C) CT scan: CT scan is not a type of bone scan. CT scans use X-rays to take images of the body in cross-sections. While they can be used to visualize bones, they are not specifically designed for bone scans. CT scans are often used to detect fractures, tumors, or other abnormalities in bones, but they do not measure bone density or metabolic activity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Radioisotope bone scan is a distinct type of imaging used to evaluate bone abnormalities through metabolic activity.

  • While bone densitometry is important for assessing bone density and fracture risk, it do not fall under the category of “bone scans” in the same context.

questions.text: Most serious complication of fracture of a long bone is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat Embolism

 

Option A)

 

  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) occurs when fat globules enter the bloodstream and obstruct blood vessels.

  • It is most commonly associated with fractures of long bones, particularly the femur, and can also occur after orthopedic surgery or trauma.

  • Typically, symptoms develop 1-3 days after the injury and can include respiratory distress (dyspnea), neurological symptoms (confusion, altered consciousness), and petechial rash (small red or purple spots on the skin).

  • Fat globules released from the bone marrow can enter the circulation during the fracture and subsequent manipulation.

  • They can occlude small blood vessels, leading to ischemia and tissue damage.

  • FES can be life-threatening, especially if it leads to significant respiratory failure or neurological impairment.

  • The mortality rate can be high if not recognized and treated promptly.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism (PE) occurs when a thrombus from the deep veins travels to the lungs, causing a blockage in the pulmonary arteries. Fractures increase the risk of venous thromboembolism due to immobility, injury to blood vessels, and other factors such as surgery or trauma. Long bone fractures, particularly in the lower extremities, are significant risk factors for PE. Symptoms may include sudden onset of shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid heartbeat, and sometimes hemoptysis. Severe cases can lead to collapse or death. PE can be a serious and life-threatening condition. It is one of the leading causes of preventable death in hospitalized patients.

 

Option C) Deep Vein Thrombosis: DVT is the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins, usually in the legs. It is a common complication following fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. Symptoms may include swelling, pain, warmth, and redness in the affected limb. However, DVT can also be asymptomatic, which makes it harder to detect. If a DVT dislodges, it can lead to a pulmonary embolism, as mentioned above. Thus, while DVT itself may not be life-threatening, it poses a significant risk for more severe complications. Prophylaxis with anticoagulants and mobilization strategies are essential to prevent DVT in patients with long bone fractures.

 

Option D) Associated Joint Injuries: Long bone fractures can often be accompanied by injuries to adjacent joints, which may affect their function, stability, and overall recovery. Common associated injuries can include ligament tears, cartilage damage, and dislocations. Joint injuries can lead to chronic pain, decreased range of motion, instability, and long-term complications such as osteoarthritis. While associated joint injuries can significantly impact the function and quality of life, they typically do not pose an immediate life threat compared to the other complications listed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis are also severe and potentially life-threatening conditions, fat embolism can present acutely after a fracture and lead to multiple organ system failure, making it particularly concerning.

questions.text: For Tuberculosis of spine, best diagnostic modality is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRI

 

Option C)

 

  • MRI is the gold standard for diagnosing tuberculosis of the spine. 

  • It provides detailed images of both bone and soft tissue structures, which are crucial in identifying vertebral destruction, abscess formation, and spinal cord involvement. 

  • MRI is highly sensitive and helps in assessing the extent of the disease and planning treatment, making it the best diagnostic tool.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clinical: While clinical signs and symptoms (e.g., back pain, neurological deficits, fever) are important for suspicion, they are not definitive for diagnosing spinal tuberculosis. Clinical assessment is often the first step, but it needs to be followed by imaging and microbiological testing for confirmation.

 

Option B. X-ray. It is the first investigation to be done in case of suspected patients. In the early stage of disease, x-rays are usually normal. X-ray can show signs of bone involvement, such as vertebral collapse, narrowing of intervertebral discs, or paraspinal abscesses. However, it is not sensitive enough to detect early disease or to assess soft tissue involvement (e.g., abscesses). X-rays are still commonly used in the initial workup but are less specific compared to MRI.

 

Option D. CT-guided biopsy: While a biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis through microbiological analysis (e.g., PCR, culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis), it is not the first-line diagnostic modality. Biopsy is typically performed when there is uncertainty after imaging or when other diagnostic tests are inconclusive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive and specific diagnostic modality for tuberculosis of the spine, as it can evaluate both bone and soft tissue involvement and is crucial in early detection and treatment planning.

questions.text: What is the earliest bony change of osteomyelitis on X-rays?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periosteal reaction

 

Option B)

 

  • Pyogenic osteomyelitis on X-ray in 24-48 hours will show loss of soft tissue planes (earliest soft tissue change on X-ray)..

  • Day 7 to 10: solid periosteal reaction (earliest bony change on X-ray).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Loss of soft tissue planes.  This is earliest x-ray finding on x-ray (soft tissue) for osteomyelitis.

 

Option C. Sequestrum.  A fragment of dead infected bone becomes separated from viable bone and is known as a sequestrum. These are late findings of chronic osteomyelitis on radiology.

 

Option D. Lytic defects.  Lytic lesions are areas where bone has been destroyed, leaving a hole in the bone. These lesions in the spine are common, and when severe, can lead to one or more vertebral compression fractures, which can be painful and even disabling.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Periosteal reaction is the earliest bony change seen on the x-ray in case of osteomyelitis, after 7-10 days.

questions.text: The father of joint replacement surgery is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Charnley

 

Option C)

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Scientist John Charnley was the father of joint replacement surgery (Arthroplasty).

questions.text: Serum alkaline phosphate is normal in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma

 

Option C)

 

  • Multiple myeloma is a haematological malignancy characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to bone lesions, anemia, and renal impairment.
  • In multiple myeloma, the ALP levels are usually normal or low because the disease is primarily destructive and not osteoblastic in nature.
  • Bone lesions caused by myeloma typically do not stimulate osteoblastic activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that often arises during periods of rapid growth, typically in adolescents and young adults. In osteosarcoma, ALP levels are usually elevated due to increased osteoblastic activity associated with the tumour. Therefore, serum ALP would not be normal.

 

Option B) Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia refers to the softening of bones due to inadequate mineralization, often resulting from vitamin D deficiency, malabsorption, or renal disease. In osteomalacia, there is often increased osteoblastic activity in an attempt to mineralize the osteoid, leading to elevated ALP levels. However, if the condition is severe or chronic, ALP may be normal or only mildly elevated, but typically, it would be elevated.

 

Option D) Malnutrition: Malnutrition can lead to various systemic effects, including deficiencies in vitamins and minerals that are crucial for bone health. It can affect bone density and metabolism. In cases of malnutrition, particularly if associated with protein-calorie malnutrition, ALP levels may be low or normal. However, it can vary depending on the specific nutritional deficiencies present.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Serum alkaline phosphatase is typically normal in multiple myeloma due to the absence of significant osteoblastic activity associated with the disease.
  • In contrast, osteosarcoma and osteomalacia are characterized by elevated ALP levels, and malnutrition can lead to variable ALP levels, but it’s most likely to be normal in the context of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man came to orthopaedic OPD with right knee pain and swelling. The clinical image is shown below. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis

 

Option D)

 

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis, resulting from wear and tear of the joint cartilage and underlying bone.
  • It typically presents with joint pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest, along with stiffness that usually resolves within 30 minutes.
  • Swelling may occur due to joint effusion.
  • X-rays may show joint space narrowing, osteophytes (bone spurs), subchondral sclerosis, and cysts.
  • In knees, there may be asymmetric involvement.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Gouty Arthritis: Gouty arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints, often related to hyperuricemia. It typically presents with sudden, severe pain, redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint. The big toe is most commonly affected, but other joints, including the knee, can also be involved. X-rays in gout may show soft tissue swelling, joint effusion, and in chronic cases, erosive changes at the joint margins, often referred to as "rat-bite" erosions. However, in the acute phase, radiographs may be normal.

 

 

Option B) Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints symmetrically, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. Patients often report morning stiffness that improves throughout the day, along with symmetrical joint involvement (both knees, for example). X-rays may show joint erosions, joint space narrowing, and periarticular osteopenia. Rheumatoid nodules may also be present outside of the joints.

 

Option C) Paget’s Disease: Paget’s disease of bone is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and weakened bones due to increased osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. It can cause bone pain, deformities, and sometimes arthritis in the affected joints. Involvement of the pelvis, spine, and long bones is common. X-rays may show thickened cortical bone, enlarged bones, and areas of osteosclerosis or osteolysis. It does not typically present acutely in the way gout or RA does.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given pathology is the osteoarthritis of the knees.
  • It is most common in older adults.
  • It presents with chronic knee pain and may show degenerative changes on radiographs.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling in the right knee after a fall during a soccer match. Examination reveals a large effusion and limited range of motion. What is the first imaging modality you would perform?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) X-ray

 

Option C)

 

  • When a patient presents with acute knee pain and swelling following a fall, an X-ray is the most appropriate initial imaging modality.
  • This is because X-rays can effectively identify fractures, which are a common cause of such symptoms after a traumatic event.
  • X-ray is preferred in this scenario because:

  • X-rays are highly sensitive for detecting fractures, especially those involving the bones of the knee joint.

  • While X-rays can miss subtle fractures, they are generally quite specific for identifying bone abnormalities.

  • If the X-ray is negative for fracture, but the patient's symptoms persist, further imaging, such as MRI, may be necessary to evaluate for soft tissue injuries.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) CT scan: A CT (computed tomography) scan uses X-rays to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body. It is useful for evaluating complex fractures or assessing bone details when there is a suspected fracture that is not well-visualized on X-ray. It can be used to assess intra-articular problems, but it is not the first-line imaging for acute knee injuries. CT scans are better suited for evaluating soft tissue injuries and complex fractures. It is not typically used as the initial imaging modality for acute knee injuries due to the availability of simpler, less invasive options. However, they involve significantly more radiation exposure than X-rays and are generally not necessary for initial evaluation of acute knee pain.

 

Option B) MRI: MRI uses magnetic fields and radio waves to create detailed images of soft tissues, including ligaments, tendons, cartilage, and the meniscus. It is excellent for evaluating soft tissue injuries, such as ligament tears (e.g., ACL or PCL injuries), meniscal tears, and other intra-articular pathology. It is also helpful in chronic cases or when there are suspicions of significant soft tissue damage. It is not typically the first step in acute trauma cases unless there are clear indications of soft tissue injury after initial assessment.

 

Option D) Ultrasound: Ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of structures within the body. It is useful for evaluating soft tissue structures, including detecting joint effusions, assessing ligament injuries, and guiding aspirations or injections. It can be helpful in pediatric populations for real-time assessment. Ultrasound can be useful for evaluating joint effusions and detecting fluid collections. It is not as effective for visualizing bone detail as X-rays.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • X-ray helps to identify any possible fractures or bony injuries before considering further imaging such as MRI or ultrasound to assess soft tissue structures.
  • X-ray is the most appropriate initial imaging modality for a 16-year-old boy presenting with acute knee pain and swelling after a fall.
  • It is highly sensitive for detecting fractures, readily available, and relatively inexpensive.
  • If the X-ray is negative, further imaging may be necessary to evaluate for soft tissue injuries.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with knee pain and limping. He has limited internal rotation of the hip, and X-rays reveal a "frog-leg" view of the hip as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perthes disease

 

Option A)

 

  • Perthes disease, or Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, is a condition characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children, typically affecting those aged 4 to 10 years.
  • The exact cause of Perthes disease is unknown, but it is thought to result from a temporary loss of blood supply to the femoral head, leading to bone necrosis.
  • Children with Perthes disease often present with hip or knee pain, limping, and limited range of motion, particularly internal rotation and abduction.
  • Symptoms can be insidious and may not always correlate with the severity of radiographic findings.
  • On X-ray, the "frog-leg" view can show various stages of the disease, including initial lateralization of the femoral head and eventual fragmentation and deformity.
  • MRI can also be used to assess the extent of necrosis.
  • Diagnosis is made through clinical evaluation, imaging studies, and sometimes MRI.
  • Given the child’s age, symptoms, and imaging findings, Perthes disease is a strong consideration.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE): SCFE is a condition in which the femoral head slips posteriorly and inferiorly due to displacement at the growth plate (physis), typically occurring in adolescents. SCFE is associated with growth plate instability and can be related to obesity or hormonal factors. It is most commonly seen during periods of rapid growth. Symptoms include hip or knee pain, limping, and reduced range of motion, particularly internal rotation. The pain may be referred to the knee, leading to initial misdiagnosis. X-rays in SCFE often show a displaced femoral head relative to the neck, particularly on the frog-leg view.

 

 

 

This condition is more common in older children and adolescents, which makes it less likely in a 10-year-old. Diagnosis is confirmed with clinical and imaging findings. While SCFE could present similarly, the patient's age and symptoms are more consistent with Perthes disease.

 

Option C) Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, typically caused by bacteria, which can occur in children following trauma or hematogenous spread. It can occur after an injury or surgery but can also arise without any clear precipitating event, particularly in immunocompromised children. Symptoms include localized bone pain, swelling, fever, and sometimes a limp. Pain may be severe and localized rather than diffuse. X-rays may show bone changes, but early osteomyelitis may not be visible until there is significant bone loss. MRI is often more sensitive for detecting early changes. Diagnosis typically involves clinical evaluation, blood tests, and imaging. Given the chronic presentation and specific findings, osteomyelitis is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D) Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly around the knee in adolescents. The exact cause is unknown, but factors may include genetic predispositions or pre-existing conditions. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass. The pain may worsen over time and is often associated with activity. X-rays may show a destructive lesion with a sunburst pattern, and an MRI or CT scan would be needed for further evaluation.

 

 

However, the acute nature of the symptoms in this case points more towards a developmental condition. Diagnosis involves imaging and often a biopsy for histological confirmation. Given the patient’s age and symptoms, osteosarcoma is less likely.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Perthes Disease fits the age of the patient, the symptom profile, and the characteristic findings on imaging, making it the most appropriate diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Joint space narrowing

 

Option B)

 

  • Joint space narrowing refers to the reduction in the distance between the opposing surfaces of a joint, often seen on X-ray or imaging studies.

  • This is one of the hallmark radiographic features of osteoarthritis.

  • As the cartilage wears away over time, the joint space decreases.

  • This narrowing is typically most pronounced in weight-bearing joints, such as the knees and hips.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Inflammation: Inflammation is a biological response to harmful stimuli, and is characterized by redness, swelling, heat, and pain. While OA does involve some inflammatory processes, particularly during flare-ups, it is primarily classified as a non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease. The inflammation observed in OA is generally mild compared to inflammatory arthritis (like rheumatoid arthritis) and is not the primary driver of the disease.

 

Option C) Bone Erosion: Bone erosion refers to the loss of bone tissue at the joint margins, often due to chronic inflammation and degradation of bone and cartilage. Unlike inflammatory arthritis, where bone erosion is a common feature (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), osteoarthritis primarily involves degeneration of cartilage without significant bone erosion. In OA, while there can be subchondral bone changes (such as sclerosis), true erosive changes are not a characteristic finding.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Joint Space Narrowing is consistently observed in patients with OA and is used to evaluate the severity and progression of the disease, distinguishing it from other forms of arthritis where inflammation and bone erosion play more prominent roles.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option A)

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the skin and mucous membranes.

  • It is the most common causative organism of septic arthritis in children, especially in cases involving older children and adolescents.

  • It can lead to rapid joint destruction if not treated promptly.

  • It can enter joints through direct inoculation (e.g., trauma, surgery) or hematogenously (from another infected site in the body).

  • Septic arthritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus typically presents with fever, swelling, redness, and severe pain in the affected joint.

  • The knee is the most commonly involved joint.

  • Treatment generally involves drainage of the infected joint and antibiotic therapy, often including methicillin or other appropriate antibiotics, depending on susceptibility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative bacterium that can cause a variety of infections, including respiratory tract infections and meningitis. This pathogen was once a common cause of septic arthritis in children, particularly those under 5 years of age, before the widespread use of the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine. It typically spreads through respiratory droplets and can lead to systemic infections, including septic arthritis, in vulnerable populations. Septic arthritis caused by H. influenzae usually presents similarly to other causes, with fever and joint pain. While it is a potential cause, its prevalence has significantly decreased due to vaccination, making it less common than Staphylococcus aureus in current clinical practice.

 

Option C) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium known for causing pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. It can cause septic arthritis, particularly in children, but is not the most common causative agent. It is more associated with infections of the respiratory system and can spread to joints. Like H. influenzae, it spreads through respiratory droplets and can lead to systemic infections, including septic arthritis. The presentation of septic arthritis caused by S. pneumoniae is similar to that of other organisms, with joint pain and swelling. Although a possible cause of septic arthritis, it is less frequently encountered than Staphylococcus aureus in children.

 

Option D) Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli (E.coli) is a gram-negative bacterium commonly found in the intestines. Some strains can cause serious infections, including urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal disease. E. coli can cause septic arthritis, particularly in neonates and children with underlying conditions, such as urinary tract infections or abdominal infections, leading to hematogenous spread. It typically enters joints through the bloodstream or following trauma. It is more common in children with specific risk factors. Symptoms are similar to other causes of septic arthritis, including joint swelling, pain, and fever. While E. coli can cause septic arthritis, it is not the most prevalent organism responsible for this condition in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of septic arthritis in children is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • While other pathogens like Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli can also cause this condition, they are less frequently encountered compared to Staphylococcus aureus in current clinical settings.

  • The emergence of antibiotic-resistant strains and the impact of vaccination programs have influenced the epidemiology of these infections over time.

questions.text: Physaliphorous cell (Larger vacuolated cells) on histopathology are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chordoma

 

Option C)

 

  • Chordoma is a rare malignant bone tumor arising from notochordal remnants, most commonly found in the axial skeleton (sacrum, clivus).
  • The hallmark of chordoma is the presence of physaliphorous cells—large, vacuolated cells that resemble bubbles and are often surrounded by a myxoid stroma.
  • These cells produce mucin and are indicative of the tumor's origin from notochordal tissue.
  • Symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and may include pain, neurological deficits, and bowel or bladder dysfunction in sacral chordomas.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, typically occurring in the metaphysis of long bones (especially around the knee). It is characterized by the presence of malignant osteoblasts and varying amounts of osteoid production. The cells are often pleomorphic and show high mitotic activity. Patients usually present with pain, swelling, and sometimes a pathological fracture. Radiologically, osteosarcomas may show a "sunburst" pattern or Codman's triangle.

 

Option B) Osteoclastoma: Osteoclastoma, or giant cell tumor of bone, is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that typically arises in the epiphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. Characterized by the presence of numerous giant cells (multinucleated osteoclast-like cells) and mononuclear stromal cells. The tumor may also have a background of reactive bone and fibrous tissue. Patients often present with joint pain and swelling, particularly in young adults (20-40 years old). X-rays typically show a lytic, subarticular lesion.

 

Option D) Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that produces cartilage and is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor, commonly found in the pelvis and long bones. Composed of chondrocytes producing a cartilage matrix. Depending on the grade, it may show varying degrees of cellularity, atypia, and calcification. Patients typically present with pain and swelling. Radiologically, it appears as a lytic lesion with calcified areas.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chordoma is characterized by physaliphorous cells, indicating its origin from notochordal remnants.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of orthopaedic rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional improvement

 

Option B)

 

  • Functional improvement is focused on restoring a patient's ability to perform daily activities and participate in their usual lifestyle.

  • This may include enhancing mobility, balance, and coordination, enabling the individual to return to work, sports, or leisure activities.

  • This is generally considered the primary goal of orthopedic rehabilitation.

  • The ultimate aim is to improve the patient's quality of life by enabling them to function effectively and independently.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Pain Management: Pain management is a crucial aspect of rehabilitation. It involves various strategies to reduce pain through medications, physical therapy modalities (like heat, cold, and electrical stimulation), and psychological support. While important, pain management is typically considered a means to an end rather than the primary goal. Reducing pain can facilitate engagement in rehabilitation activities but does not encompass the full scope of rehabilitation's objectives.

 

Option C) Strength Gain: Strength gain involves exercises and activities designed to increase muscle power and endurance. This can be a significant component of rehabilitation, especially following surgery or injury. While strengthening is vital for recovery and overall function, it is typically a subset of the broader objective of functional improvement. Gaining strength contributes to functional abilities but is not the sole focus.

 

Option D) Range of Motion Improvement: Improving range of motion (ROM) involves exercises and interventions aimed at increasing joint mobility. This is essential for regaining function, particularly after injuries or surgeries that may limit movement. Like strength gain, improving ROM is crucial but is considered one aspect of the overall goal of functional improvement. Enhanced range of motion supports functional tasks but is not the ultimate aim of rehabilitation.

 

Educational objective: 

 

  • Functional improvement captures the overarching objective of orthopaedic rehabilitation, which is to enhance the patient's ability to engage in daily activities and improve their quality of life.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salmonella

 

Option A)

 

  • Patients with sickle cell anemia have a unique susceptibility to certain infections, including osteomyelitis due to several factors like functional asplenia and areas of bone infarction, which create an environment conducive to bacterial growth. 
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, in individuals with sickle cell disease, Salmonella species are disproportionately common.
  • The vaso-occlusive crises characteristic of sickle cell disease can lead to micro-infarctions in the bone marrow. 
  • These areas of ischemic and necrotic bone can serve as a nidus for bacterial infection, particularly by gut-derived organisms like Salmonella.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Streptococcus: Streptococcus is the common causative organism in patients with osteomyelitis normally. 

 

Option C. Haemophilus: This organism is responsible for septic arthritis. 

 

Option D. Neisseria: This also causes septic arthritis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease is caused due to salmonella infection. 
  • Different etiologies for osteomyelitis are:

questions.text: X-ray shoulder of the patient with following image shows:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

Option D)

 

  • Observe the sequestrum surrounded by less dense granulation tissue and new bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma.  Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma.  Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given X-ray image shows sequestrum in the centre surrounded by the involucrum and deformed bone in the chronic osteomyelitis of the upper end of the humerus.

questions.text: Most common organism for Postsurgical osteomyelitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus

 

Option A)

 

  • Commonest causative organism for Post-traumatic osteomyelitis/Post-surgical osteomyelitis - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Bacterial biofilms attached to orthopedic devices implanted during the operation can increase the rate of postoperative osteomyelitis infection.
  • Open fractures are potentially more prone to the development of postoperative osteomyelitis infection because of the direct intrusion of foreign bacterial flora.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas. This organism causes multifocal and recurrent osteomyelitis, and septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Streptococcus. β-hemolytic streptococci is responsible for causing post-streptococcal reactive arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common organism for post-surgical osteomyelitis is staphylococcus aureus.

choices.text: Most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: True about HIV-associated osteomyelitis is all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Necrosis absent

 

Option A) 

 

OSTEOMYELITIS IN AIDS

 

  • Osteomyelitis involves inflammation of bone and bone marrow, often leading to bone destruction and necrosis. 
  • HIV patients are more susceptible to conditions like avascular necrosis. 
  • In the bacterial osteomyelitis, bone necrosis is a hallmark.
  • Staphylococcus is the most common organism and often it is bilateral.
  • As pathophysiology of osteomyelitis is not altered, all the pathological changes seen in other osteomyelitis are seen in AIDS also.
  1. Dead necrotic bone (necrosis is present)
  2. Periosteal reaction (periosteal new bone formation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Often bilateral: While osteomyelitis can be multifocal or affect multiple bones in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, but it is not always strictly bilateral. However, avascular necrosis, which is common in HIV patients, can indeed be bilateral. 

 

Option C. Periosteal new bone formation: Periosteal new bone formation (periosteal reaction) is a common radiological feature of osteomyelitis regardless of the patient's HIV status. The periosteum lays down new bone in response to inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. Most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus: Similar to the general population, Staphylococcus aureus remains the most common causative organism for bacterial osteomyelitis in individuals with HIV. While HIV patients can be susceptible to opportunistic infections, S. aureus is still the predominant pathogen for osteomyelitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In HIV-associated osteomyelitis, the most commonly found causative organism is the staphylococcus. 
  • The infection often presents bilaterally. 
  • The two commonly seen pathological features are necrosis of the bone and periosteal new bone formation.

questions.text: The most common organism causing osteomyelitis in drug abusers is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas

 

Option B)

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is most common organism in intravenous drug users and Salmonella is the most common organism in sickle cell anemia patients.
     

  • Extremity infections in Intravenous Drug Abusers (IVDA) can be due localised reaction at the injection site or due to haematogenous spread.
     

  • There have been an increase in the incidence of soft tissue abscess, osteomyelitis and septic arthritis presentations.

  • Initial literature suggested Pseudomonas species as the most common organism while Staphylococcus aureus was the most common organism three decades ago.
     

  • Most common organism overall – staph aureus
     

  • M/c in Genitourinary infection – E. coli
     

  • In neonates – heamophillus / group B streptococci

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In drug abusers, the most commonly found organism as the cause of osteomyelitis is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: Non-healing sinus is a common clinical feature is chronic osteomyelitis. The most common frequent cause for this presentation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of sequestrum

 

Option C)

 

  • Due to necrosis, pieces of dead bone separate as sequestra which are varying in size from spicule to large segment. It is lighter than live bone and normal pattern of bone is lost.

  • It acts as nidus and is most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis.

 

 

  • It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis.

  • Chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge can be seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Resistant organism. With wide utilization of antibiotics, mutation leads to resistant organism such as MRSA, VRSA. Such organisms are also causative agents for non-healing wound in case of chronic osteomyelitis.

 

Option B. Retained foreign body. Foreign body-induced osteomylitis – Since it is organic, it acts as a vulnerable medium for infections, hence retained wound foreign bodies may also result in fistula formation along with cellulitis or abscess formation as well as osteomyelitis and synovitis.

 

Option D. Intraosseous cavities. In chronic osteomyelitis, disruption of the intraosseous and periosteal blood supply leads to formation of a necrotic bone fragment. Such necrosis can form intraosseous cavities which cause non-healing sinus formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presence of the sequestrum is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis.

choices.text: ESR and white blood cell counts are usually normal
Ultrasound of the joint reveals widening of the joint space
The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

questions.text: Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) of the hip is characterized by all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

 

Option D)

 

TRANSIENT (TOXIC) SYNOVITIS OF HIP

 

  • It is self-limiting, inflammatory condition of synovium.
  • It is the common cause of hip pain and limping in children of 6 to 12 years of age.
  • Boys are affected 2-3 times more than girls.
  • 95% cases are unilateral.
  • A recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection of viral origin is usually present.
  • The joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation because in this position, the joint capacity is maximum (so stretching due to effusion is minimal), thus causing least pain.
  • Physical examination is characterized by guarded rotation of hip joint.
  • Pain can be elicited at the extreme of motion.
  • The patient is non-toxic and rarely have temperature above 38˚C or any indications of systemic illness.
  • The white blood cells (WBC) count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Radiographs are normal or have slightly widened joint space medially.
  • Ultrasound reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveals a WBC count between 5,000 and 15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The transient synovitis of the hip is usually a manifestation after an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • On physical examination, the hip joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation position (FABER).
  • ESR and WBC levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Ultrasound investigation of the hip reveals mild effusion and widened joint space.

questions.text: Septic arthritis in a 2-year-old child is often caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option B) 

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis in all ages.
  • Typical pathogens for septic arthritis in different pediatric age groups:
    • Neonates (0-1 month): Group B Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, and Gram-negative bacilli (e.g., E. coli) are common.
    • Infants and Young Children (1 month to ~3-5 years):
      • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause across all pediatric age groups, including this one.
      • Kingella kingae has emerged as an important cause in children under 2-3 years, often being a more subtle or less acutely severe infection.
      • Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was a significant cause historically, but its incidence has dramatically reduced in vaccinated populations due to the Hib vaccine. However, non-typeable H. influenzae or other serotypes can still cause infections, though less commonly.
  • Older Children and Adolescents: Staphylococcus aureus remains prevalent. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) can also be seen. Neisseria gonorrhoeae should be considered in sexually active adolescents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: The most common infections caused by H.influenzae are pneumonia, meningitis, cellulitis, infectious arthritis etc.

 

Option C. Gonococci: Gonococcal Arthritis in toddlers is a rare occurrence. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The causative organism of septic arthritis in a 2-year-old child is often the staphylococcus aureus. 
  • Haemophilus influenzae was historically relevant, but widespread vaccination has reduced its prevalence significantly. 
  • Gonococcal arthritis is associated with sexual activity or perinatal transmission, neither of which is typical for a 2-year-old. 
  • Pneumococci can cause septic arthritis but are far less common than Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Madura mycosis

 

Option B)

 

  • Madura mycosis (Mycetoma) is a chronic, progressively destructive infection of skin, subcutaneous tissue, fascia, and bone, often involving the foot. 
  • It is characterized by a "triad" of:
  • Swelling
  • Multiple discharging sinuses
  • Pus containing "grains" or "granules" (colonies of the causative organism)
  • Mycetoma can be caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma, caused by Actinomyces or Nocardia species). 
  • KOH smear would show filamentous structures (hyphae for eumycetoma, or branching filaments for actinomycetoma). 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteomyelitis: This is a bacterial infection of the bone. Presenting complaints are Fever (>38.3˚C), swelling of the limb, pain, systemic symptoms and increased levels of total leucocyte counts, ESR and CRP. Blood Culture is positive for staphylococcus aureus in 60% cases.

 

Option C. Anthrax: Anthrax is a bacterial infection (caused by Bacillus anthracis) that can manifest as cutaneous anthrax (a black eschar), inhalation anthrax, or gastrointestinal anthrax. This commonly presents with non-specific prodromal symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and sweats which progress to dyspnea and ultimately, respiratory failure and hemodynamic collapse. In cutaneous anthrax, the diagnosis is mostly clinical. However, confirmation can be established by the culture of the lesion, serologic testing, or punch biopsy. In inhalation anthrax, CT scanning of the chest is more sensitive. Sputum culture, gram stain, and blood cultures are not helpful in the acute phase. 

 

Option D. Actinomycosis: This is a chronic, suppurative (pus-forming) bacterial infection caused by Actinomyces species, which are filamentous bacteria. It frequently occurs at an oral, cervical or facial site, usually as a soft tissue swelling, abscess or mass that is often mistaken for neoplasm. Angle of jaw is most commonly involved. Involvement of bone is usually due to adjacent soft tissues. Mandible is most commonly involved. Vertebrae (spreading from lung or gut) or pelvis (spreading from cecum or colon) may also be involved. Infection of an extremity is uncommon. X-ray show cystic areas of bone destruction with concomitant bone formation and bone destruction. It is a type of actinomycetoma, which falls under the broader category of Mycetoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis. 
  • The filamentous structures observed on a KOH smear in Madura mycosis are hyphae which are the thread-like structures that make up the body of a fungus.
  • In Madura mycosis, the hyphae are typically thick-walledand septate (divided into compartments).
  • This presents as swelling of the extremity, pus discharge, and multiple sinuses.

questions.text: Index finger infection spreads to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thenar space

 

Option A)

 

THENAR SPACE

 

  • It is lateral to lateral septum and must not be confused with the fascial compartment containing the thenar muscles.

  • It lies posterior to the long flexor tendons to the index finger and in front of the adductor pollicis muscle and contains the first lumbricals muscles.

 

 

Spaces of hand diagrammatic representation

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The infection from the index finger can spread to the thenar space of the hand.

questions.text: Tuberculosis with polyarthritis is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Poncet’s disease

 

OPTION A:

 

PONCET’S DISEASE

 

  • Polyarthritis that occurs during acute tuberculosis infection.

  • It is a form of sterile reactive arthritis that develops in active TB.

  • It is a rare, non-destructive, para-infective, symmetric polyarthritis.

  • No mycobacterial involvement or other known cause of polyarthritis can be found.

  • Associated with multiple small joint arthritis.

  • Chronic arthritis is not encountered in PD.

  • It is thought to occur due to a hypersensitive immune cell mediated response to the tuberculoprotein, resulting in an inflammatory reaction in the joint spaces.

  • Due to the rarity of PD despite the frequency of TB, a genetic predisposition has been suggested in the pathogenesis, with links to the HLA DR3 and HLA DR4 haplotypes.

  • Poncet’s arthritis is non-destructive and resolves completely following TB treatment.

  • The arthritis mainly affects the larger joints, with the knee being the most common, followed by the ankle and wrist joints.

  • The axial skeleton is not involved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. von Gierke’s disease. Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), also known as Von Gierke disease, is an inherited disorder caused by deficiencies of specific enzymes in the glycogen metabolism pathway. It comprises of 2 subtypes, GSD Ia and GSD Ib. In GSD Ia, there is a deficiency of enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. Patients with GSD 1b have normal G6Pase enzyme activity but have a deficiency of the transporter enzyme, glucose-6-phosphate translocase (G6PT), manifesting as hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis typically around 3 to 4 months of age. In suspected patients, genetic testing is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis. Dietary treatment prevents hypoglycemia and improves the life expectancy of patients.

 

Option D. Gordon’s disease. Gordon Syndrome is a rare, inherited disorder that affects movement in the joints of the upper and lower limbs, also known as distal arthrogryposis. Patients can be born with several fingers fixed in a flexed position (camptodactyly), clubfoot, and an opening in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate). Their joints are often very stiff or unable to move. Intelligence is usually normal. Gordon syndrome is caused by genetic mutations in the PIEZO2 gene and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Gordon syndrome is diagnosed by clinical examination and genetic testing. Treatment is directed at the symptoms and includes surgery and physical therapy to loosen the joints.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis with polyarthritis is called Poncet’s disease, a reactive arthritis that occurs during the active stage of TB.

questions.text: Tuberculosis in bone is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paucibacillary and hematogenous

 

Option A:

 

  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes that is usually secondary.

  • The route of spread is mostly hematogenous (through artery and Bateson's plexus).

  • The lesions are Paucibacillary.

  • Pulmonary Koch’s is multibacillary and caused mainly by aerosol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Multibacillary and hematogenous. Multibacillary lesions spread by hematogenous dissemination are seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Multibacillary and lymphatic. Multibacillary lesions spread by lymphatic dissemination are also seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis of bone occurs due to spread from the hematogenous route from a primary site, usually lungs.

  • The lesions in bone TB are paucibacillary i.e., the skin smear appears to be negative and there is no advancement evident on biopsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady came with chronic backache. On X-ray, she had a D12 collapse. But intervertebral disc space is maintained. All are possible except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis

 

Option D:

 

  • Characteristic radiological feature of Pott’s spine is obliteration of disc space with destruction of two adjacent vertebrae.

  • This feature differentiates TB spine from other diseases causing vertebral destruction (like metastasis) in which disc space is preserved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma. This involves spinal cord compression due to vertebral body collapse and extradural extension of the tumor.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis. This involves compression fracture of the vertebral bodies.

 

Option C. Metastasis. Spinal metastasis has a defining feature of sparing of the intervertebral disc space.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • All the given conditions in the question have the intervertebral space maintained except for tuberculous lesions which involves the destruction of the vertebral body as well as the intervertebral space and disc.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male HIV positive on antiretroviral therapy has pain in right hip region. Flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity of right hip is present for 2 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TB Hip

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Avascular necrosis. This is less commonly seen in HIV patients. If present, there is flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformity (FADIR) of the hip.

 

Option C. Transient synovitis. This is seen in pediatric patients. Since, here the patient is an adult, this option can be ruled out.

 

Option D. Septic arthritis. This is also seen commonly in pediatric patients. Since, here the patient is an adult, this option can also be ruled out.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity of the hip in an HIV positive adult patient is suggestive of TB of the hip.

  • Since AVN of the hip in HIV positive patients show FADIR deformity, and other two options of transient synovitis and septic arthritis are commonly seen in pediatric patients, the best answer for the given question is TB of the hip.

questions.text: Complication of hip joint TB is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrous ankylosis

 

  • The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in spine is the bony ankylosis and in peripheral joints like Hip and Knee Fibrous ankylosis is seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bony ankylosis. This is seen as a result of tuberculosis of the spine.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common complication of hip joint TB is fibrous ankylosis.

questions.text: Triple deformity of knee is classically seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

TRIPLE DEFORMITY OF KNEE

 

  • There is posterior subluxation of tibia, external rotation of tibia over the femoral condyles, and flexion at the knee joint.
  • It is usually seen in tuberculosis of knee and rheumatoid arthritis or post-traumatic, incompletely reduced, old, neglected dislocated knee. 
  • It can also be seen in Iliotibial band contracture, poliomyelitis and hemophilic arthropathy.
  • The "triple deformity" of the knee refers to a combination of 3 distinct deformities commonly seen in advanced knee conditions such as untreated or severe tuberculosis arthritis, certain neurological disorders, and some types of joint contractures. 
  • The development of a triple deformity in the knee often involves a complex interplay of factors, typically resulting from chronic inflammation, infection, muscle imbalance, or joint degeneration. 
  • Flexion Contracture (Flexion Deformity):
    • Chronic inflammation or infection, such as from tuberculosis or rheumatoid arthritis, can lead to synovial hypertrophy, joint effusion, and fibrotic changes around the joint capsule.
    • Over time, this can cause the knee to remain in a flexed position, and adhesions form around the knee joint, restricting extension.
    • Spasticity or weakness in muscles like the quadriceps also contributes to an inability to extend the knee fully.
  • Varus or Valgus Deformity:
    • Due to asymmetric joint destruction, as seen in osteoarthritis or tuberculosis, there may be more damage on one side of the knee than the other.
    • For example, in osteoarthritis, there is often more cartilage and bone loss medially, leading to a varus deformity.
    • Conversely, lateral compartment damage leads to a valgus deformity.
    • Muscle imbalances or ligament laxity on either side of the knee can further exacerbate the angulation.
  • External Rotation Deformity:
    • Chronic inflammation or damage to the knee joint affects the alignment between the femur and tibia, leading to compensatory external rotation of the tibia.
    • Muscle weakness, especially in the medial rotators of the knee, contributes to this deformity, as stronger external rotators overpower them.
    • Ligamentous instability and misalignment further worsen the rotational malalignment, often causing an outward rotation of the tibia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of triple deformity of the knee is tuberculosis of the knee joint. 
  • Triple deformity is more common in TB of the knee than in other types of arthritis because it is a chronic infection and the bacteria slowly destroy the joint tissues, leading to the development of deformities. 
  • Another reason is that TB often affects the posterior capsule of the knee joint, which stabilize the joint. When this ligament is damaged, it can allow the knee to become unstable and deformed.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the X-ray depicted below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

Option B:

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic.
  • The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.

 

 

  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells).
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.
  • Treatment options:
    • Extended Curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – procedure of choice for most lesions
    • Excision of lower end of ulna, upper end of fibula
    • Excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft – lower end of radius where upper end of fibula is grafted
    • Excision and arthrodesis or prosthetic replacement or Turn-O-Plasty (Bone ends are cut and rotated) – lower end femur and upper end tibia
    • Amputation
    • Malignant recurrent GCT – Radiotherapy

 

Explanation:
